0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono: Vitreomacular adhesion, Symptomatic: 0.125 mg (0.1 mL of diluted solution) via INTRAVITREAL INJECTION to the affected eye once as a single dose

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: specific contraindications have not been determined

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• dyschromatopsia, in some cases associated with electroretinographic changes, has been reported
  • intraocular inflammation, infection, and hemorrhage have been reported
  • intraocular pressure increases have been reported
  • lens subluxation has been reported with higher than recommended doses
  • retinal detachment and retinal tear, mostly occurring during or after vitrectomy, has been reported
  • visual acuity, decreased, has been reported; may indicate progression of condition; monitoring recommended

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
Ophthalmic:Blurred vision (5% to 20%), Conjunctival hemorrhage (5% to 20%), Macular hole (5% to 20%), Pain in eye (5% to 20%), Photopsia (5% to 20%), Retinal edema (5% to 20%), Uveitis (7.1%), Visual impairment (5% to 20%), Vitreous floaters (5% to 20%)
Serious
Ophthalmic:Cataract (2% to less than 5%), Degeneration of retina (2% to less than 5%), Reduced visual acuity (5% to 20%), Retinal detachment (0.4% to 0.9%), Retinal tear (up to 1.1%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Ocriplasmin, a truncated form of human plasmin with proteolytic activity against protein components of the vitreous body and the vitreoretinal interface, dissolves the protein matrix responsible for vitreomacular adhesion.

2.title: Metabolism
2.mono: Rapidly via endogenous protein catabolism pathway

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intravitreal
  • allow vial to thaw to room temperature; add 0.2 mL NS and gently swirl
  • withdraw solution from vial with 19-gauge needle; replace with 30-gauge needle for administration
  • administer solution immediately after dilution, under controlled aseptic conditions with adequate anesthesia and broad spectrum microbicide
  • insert needle 3.5 to 4 mm posterior to limbus; avoid horizontal meridian; inject into mid-vitreous
  • intended for single use only; discard any unused product, use new vial, and change sterile field if contralateral eye also requires injection

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• improvement in signs and symptoms of vitreomacular adhesion is indicative of efficacy.
  • decreased vision
  • intraocular pressure; immediately following administration

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Warn patient to use caution when doing activities requiring mental alertness or coordination, such as driving a car or operating heavy machinery until effects are known, as drug may cause visual impairment.
  • Drug may cause eye pain, blurred vision, visual impairment, and retinal edema.
  • Advise patient to immediately report signs/symptoms of endophthalmitis or retinal detachment (ie, eye pain, eye redness, photophobia, blurred or decreased vision).
  • Instruct patient to immediately report signs/symptoms of intraocular infection or inflammation including redness, pain, sensitivity to light, or changes in vision.
